Stop, Warning and Message

Source: R/err.R
err.Rd

Wrappers on abort(), warn() and inform().

err(..., n = NULL, .subclass = NULL)

wrn(..., n = NULL, .subclass = NULL)

msg(..., n = NULL, .subclass = NULL)

Arguments

...

zero or more objects which can be coerced to character (and which are pasted together with no separator) or a single condition object.
n

The value of n for converting sprintf-like types.
.subclass

Subclass of the condition. This allows your users to selectively handle the conditions signalled by your functions.

Functions

  • err: Error

  • wrn: Warning

  • msg: Message

sprintf-like types

The following sprintf-like types can be used in the custom messages:

n

The value of n.

s

'' if n == 1 otherwise 's'

r

'is' if n == 1 otherwise 'are'

Examples


# err
try(err("this is an error"))
#> Error : this is an error
#> Backtrace:
#>      █
#>   1. ├─base::tryCatch(...)
#>   2. │ └─base:::tryCatchList(expr, classes, parentenv, handlers)

#>   5. │   └─base:::tryCatchList(expr, names[-nh], parentenv, handlers[-nh])
#>   6. │     └─base:::tryCatchOne(expr, names, parentenv, handlers[[1L]])
#>   7. │       └─base:::doTryCatch(return(expr), name, parentenv, handler)
#>   8. ├─base::withCallingHandlers(...)

#>  12. └─(function (..., crayon_enabled, crayon_colors, pkgdown_internet) ...

#>  37.                           │     └─base:::tryCatchOne(expr, names, parentenv, handlers[[1L]])
#>  38.                           │       └─base:::doTryCatch(return(expr), name, parentenv, handler)
#>  39.                           └─chk::err("this is an error")

# wrn
wrn("this is a warning")
#> Warning: this is a warning
wrn("there %r %n problem value%s")
#> Warning: there %r %n problem value%s
wrn("there %r %n problem value%s", n = 1)
#> Warning: there is 1 problem value
wrn("there %r %n problem value%s", n = 2)
#> Warning: there are 2 problem values

# msg
msg("this is a message")
#> this is a message
msg("there %r %n problem value%s")
#> there %r %n problem value%s
msg("there %r %n problem value%s", n = 1)
#> there is 1 problem value
msg("there %r %n problem value%s", n = 2)
#> there are 2 problem values
